prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author of the Reddit-style post is in the wrong. The situation is about a husband setting up his office in the bedroom, causing disruptions for the author who also works from home and handles most chores and kids.

First, I need to parse the key points. The husband works from home a few days a week, chose the bedroom over the basement because of the view. His job is mostly conference calls, so the wife has to keep the kids from disturbing him. This means the top floor is off-limits, and she can't do chores, shower, etc. She suggested the basement for him, which would be quieter. She's working from home too and does most housework. She told him she can't promise silence if he's in the bedroom, but if he uses the basement, they won't disturb him. Now they're fighting about who's the asshole.

The question is whether the author (the wife) is in the wrong. The options are A (yes) or B (no). 

So, I need to evaluate from both sides. The husband's choice to work in the bedroom is affecting her ability to work and manage the household. She's already handling a lot, and his setup is causing her to lose personal time and efficiency. The husband is being resistant to moving to the basement despite having the space, just for a better view. That seems a bit self-centered. 

On the other hand, maybe the husband has a valid reason for wanting to work in the bedroom. But the issue is that his choice is causing significant inconvenience to his wife, who's also working and managing the household. The wife is trying to find a compromise by offering the basement, which is a reasonable solution. The husband's refusal to move is the root of the problem. 

In terms of fairness, setting up an office in a shared space without considering the impact on a partner can be problematic. Since the wife is the one handling most of the domestic responsibilities, the husband's decision limits her ability to do her job and take care of the house. The wife is trying to set boundaries by suggesting an alternative that would minimize disruption, which is logical. 

Therefore, the husband's refusal to move to the basement when it's feasible is the main issue here. The author isn't at fault because she's trying to balance both their needs and the household responsibilities. The husband is prioritizing his comfort over her ability to function, which isn't fair. So the answer is B, the author is not in the wrong.
